Democratic Hopeful
Weaver To Lecture
On Housing Affairs Opposes Open Housing
By MARSHALL PAUL
Robert C. Weaver, who will deliver the
annual Albert and Gloria Lion Lecture
4 p.m. Sunday in Shriver Hall, has worn
the tag of "Society's Advance Man" ever
Since his appointment as Secretary of
Housing and Urban Development in Jantutry.
A Harvard Ph.D. and the first Negro
to hold a cabinet post, Weaver has been
described as "smart, articulate, and
thorough going."
Leaders Cool
Because of his lack of identification
With the Negro revolution—even in the
Past five years—Negro civil rights leaders
have been cool to him, Business Week
Magazine noted recently.
However, Weaver has come out strongly
in favor of mixed housing for different
economic classes within the- same neighborhood.
"It's not going to work in every city
Or every neighborhood in a city, but it's
got to occur if we're going to make housing units available to non-whites in subtirbia," he says.
Public Isn't Ready
The biggest problem today, Weaver
eiaims, is that the public isn't ready to
Confront the problems of the cities
bead-on.
In his first year as Secretary, Weaver
has been outspoken on such subjects as
rent subsidy programs and FHA insurance backing.

SC Petitions For Boat Ride Raided Walters Gallery
Up For City Loan
Bookstore Review.
By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
The Student Council has entered into another
phase of what it calls its fight against "profiteering"
by the Johns Hopkins Bookstore.
This phase consists of petitions which are being
circulated throughout the school accusing the bookstore of selling overpriced books and calling for a
review and subsequent change of the bookstore's policies. The reason for the petitions is to show the Administration that the students are dissatisfied with the
operations of the bookstore.
Jim Jacobs, a sophomore and a member of the
Student Council, is presently preparing a study of the
operations of the Hopkins bookstore' and other college bookstores throughout the country. The report is
due November 15th.
Sponsor Boycott
Council President Bill Reinsch has asked the proper
•
authorities in the Administration to respond to the
report by December 15th. If the Administration does
not commit itself to improvement of the situation,
Reinsch said that the Council would sponsor a boyoott of the bookstore for the second semester of this
school year.
Reinsch added that "we hope it won't be necessary,
but we are prepared to set up our own operation
bo serve the students."
Plans have already been made by the Council to
supply the students with their books should the boysat be put into effect. The important details however,
have not been worked out in the hope that the bookstore situation will be improved considerably by the
Second semester.

Baltimore city voters in the November 8 election
will have an opportunity to approve a $1,100,000 city
loan to the Walters Art Gallery.
The expansion bond issue has caused marked concern at the University, since the Walters is used as a
reference source for much of the literary and archeological survey work done by the Department of Classics.
The present Walters building and the associated
collection were deeded to the City of Baltimore by
Henry Walters upon his death in 1931.
Mr. Walters completed construction of the biulding
In 1908 to serve as a private gallery. Even at that time
its facilities were barely adequate to house his entire
collection.

Katz!
To the Editors:
You and your horny friends
may be happy to learn that Wisconsin State U. at Eau Claire
(NL; Oct. 14, 1966) has an enrollment approaching 5,000. Odds
are between 3-2 and 2-1 women.
Almost all of which have breasts.
Your article, however, was not
bad on the whole. Really rather
interesting. (Please excuse the
gross pun I just discovered two
sentences back.)
How did you ever choose Eau
Claire?
B. Morrow.
•• *

Hopkins Retorts
To the Editors:
For many years, a favorite
topic of journalists from coast to
coast was that "loudmouthed
slob," the Brooklyn Dodgers fan.
This fellow did everything wrong.
He even had his own peculiar
dialect, incomprehensible to anyone except another fan.
Now our earnest reporter, Mr.
Brecher, is seeking DO institutionalize a new journalistic topic,
the Baltimore fan. This "moron"
also has a funny way of talking,
but that's not his only serious
problem. Not by a long shot!
The poor guy doesn't know how
to drink champagne! Worse yet,
he doesn't even know how to buy
decent champagne! Holy Faux
Big
Pas! Golly Gaucheness!!
Deal, When did champagne finesse become a valid means of
judging a man, or a city? For
that matter, when did honest.enthusiasm, a bit unsophisticated
perhaps, but honest, become a
fault?
It has always amazed me that
jerks from every whistle-stop in
the Western World can come to
Baltimore and within a few days
set themselves up as experts on
"what's wrong with this town."
Maybe its insecurity that causes
this apparent need for tickertape welcoming parades and a
gold key to the city for every incoming student. But whatever
the cause, the uninformed criticism of Poclunk People, although
a bit rude, and slightly annoy-

ing, dont really deserve much of
an answer.
But Mr. Brecher, a noble New
Yorker, may merit some kind of
an answer. So to him this bit of
knowledge: every city has its
good side and its backside including Baltimore. If our earnest
reporter has a blind affinity for
the backsides of things, that's his
problem; it shouldnt have to be
ours weekly. If on the other
hand, Baltimore has chosen to
show only her backside to our
earnest reporter, then perhaps
she has once again evidenced the
good taste he is so convinced she
lacks.
Wallace Hopkins, '67.

We wonder as President Johnson makes the rounds
of the Asian capitals if he remembers Private Milton
Olive. Olive, a young negro was awarded a posthumous
Congressional Medal of Honor last year when he fell on
a grenade that threatened to wipe out the remaining
members of his squad.
We might speculate (without the intention of dishonoring the heroism of Olive's act) that the idea may
have occurred to him to fall on the grenade because he
had once seen Aldo Ray do the same thing in a war movie.
Further it would appear that much of our behavior is
directed by the theatrical conditioning we have received
at the hands of the film makers. Every new waitress who
appears on a job has a cinematic conception of how a
waitress is supposed to act. The motions of slopping a
cloth on a formica counter are already second nature.
It is not, therefore, terribly hard to imagine President Johnson conducting himself in office in the manner
in which he saw Ralph Bellamy interpret Franklin D.
Roosevelt or Raymond Massey as Abraham Lincoln.
While Johnson is the President he also plays the President and it is whether he does both things well that is
the heart of the Government's attitude toward the war in
Viet-Nam.
Those who saw David Lean's film revision of
Boris Pasternak's Dr. Zhivago have not found it difficult
to erase the memory of Rita Tushingham in overhalls.
Yet if we as a nation continue to confuse film with political reality it would be best to remember the obvious
irony of a British film maker attempting to capture the
spirit of Soviet Russia 1917 on location in fascist Spain
1966 for we must begin to determine whether we agree
with Professor Bernard Fall's allegation that Viet-Nam
does not represent Munich 1938 but Spain 1936.
It is useless to attempt to consider the feelings of
poor Pasternak whose novel was certainly butchered.
Nevertheless Lean's Zhivago provides a meaningful vantage from which to consider the motivation for fighting in
Vietnam and the rationality of a political war (as opposed to a moral one) as well.

ONCE MORE UNTO THE BREACH
Way back in 1953 I started writing this column about
campus life. Today, a full 13 years later, I am still writing
this column,for my interest in undergraduates is as keen
and lively as ever. This is called "arrested development:'
But where else can a writer find a subject as fascinating
as the American campus? Where else are minds so nettled,
bodies so roiled, psyches so unglued?
Right now,for example,though the new school year has
just begun, you've already encountered the following disasters:
1. You hate your teachers,
2. You hate your courses.
3. You hate your room-mates.
4. You have no time to study.
5. You have no place to study.
Friends,let us, without despair, examine your problems
one by one.
1. You hate your teachers. For shame, friends! Try
looking at things their way. Take your English teacher,
for instance. Here's a man who is one of the world's
authorities on Robert Browning, yet he wears $30 tweeds
and a pre-war necktie while his brother Sam,a high school
dropout, earns 70 thou a year in aluminum siding. Is it so
hard to understand why he writes "F" on top of your
themes and "Eeeyich!" in the margin? Instead of hating
him, should you not admire his dedication to scholarship,
his disdain for the blandishments of commerce? Of course
you should. You may flunk, but Pippa passes.
2. You hate your courses. You say, for example, that
you don't see the use of studying Macbeth when you are
majoring in veterinary medicine. You're wrong, friends.
Believe me,some day when you are running a busy kennel,
you'll be mighty glad you learned "Out, damned Spot!"
3. You hate your room-mates. This is, unquestionably,
a big problem—in fact, the second biggest problem on
American campuses. (The first biggest, of course, is on
which side of your mortar board do you dangle the tassel
at Commencement?) But there is an answer to the roommate probleM: keep changing room-mates. The optimum
interval, I have found, is every four hours.
4. You have no time to study. Friends, I'm glad to report there is a simple way to find extra time in your busy
schedule. All you have to do is buy some Personna Super
Stainless Steel Blades. Then you won't be wasting precious hours hacking away with inferior blades, mangling
your face again and again in a tedious, feckless effort to
winnow your whiskers. Personna shaves you quickly and
slickly, easily and breezily, hacklessly, scrapelessly, tuglessly, nicklessly, scratchlessly, matchlessly. Furthermore,
Personna Blades last and last. Moreover, they are available both in double-edge and Injector style. And, as if this
weren't enough, Personna is now offering you a chance to
grab a fistful of $100 bills. The Personna Super Stainless
Steel Sweepstakes is off and running! You can win $10,000
and even more. Get over to your Personna dealer for details and an entry blank. Don't just stand there!
5. You have no place to study. This is a thorny one, I'll
admit, what with the library so jammed and the dorms so
noisy. But with a little ingenuity, you can still find a quiet,
deserted spot—like the ticket office of the lacrosse team.
Or a testimonial dinner for the dean. Or the nearest recruiting station.

CAMPUS NOTES
Graduate Club
The Graduate Clubroom is
open every night from 7:00 p.m.
until 2:00 a.m., except Sunday.
Food, beer, and wine are served
under the supervision of a new
bartender, Mrs, Case.
The clubroom is decorated with
12 new paintings, commissioned
by the club from Bob Wang. An
athletic display board is planned.
The present membership of

the club numbers over 500. Tom
Kelly, club president, announced
that two positions on the board
are open. Each position will be
filled within ten days of receipt
of the first nomination.

Venetian Lecture
W. R. Rearick, Assistant Professor of the Hopkins' Department of Fine Arts, will present an
18th century view of Venice as
seen by an imaginary English

gentleman and his wife on the
grand tour in 1782 at The Baltimore Museum of Art October
25 at 8:15 p.m.
The "flash-back" guided tour
of the city built on 117 islands
will be illustrated with slides of
the period, most of which are
in oolor.
Rearick has studied and lived
in Italy and devoted much of his
research and study to the arts
of Italy.
Admission is free.

Eastern High School will be
the sight of the Big Fall concert

Simon and Garfunkel write

city-dweller in an unusual and
highly engrossing manner to
their audiences.
Simon and Garfunkel have
produced a succession of hits

them as the up-and-coming
force on the folk music scene.

Weaver To Lecture
On Housing Affairs Opposes Open Housing
By MARSHALL PAUL
Robert C. Weaver, who will deliver the
annual Albert and Gloria Lion Lecture
4 p.m. Sunday in Shriver Hall, has worn
the tag of "Society's Advance Man" ever
Since his appointment as Secretary of
Housing and Urban Development in Jantutry.
A Harvard Ph.D. and the first Negro
to hold a cabinet post, Weaver has been
described as "smart, articulate, and
thorough going."
Leaders Cool
Because of his lack of identification
With the Negro revolution—even in the
Past five years—Negro civil rights leaders
have been cool to him, Business Week
Magazine noted recently.
However, Weaver has come out strongly
in favor of mixed housing for different
economic classes within the- same neighborhood.
"It's not going to work in every city
Or every neighborhood in a city, but it's
got to occur if we're going to make housing units available to non-whites in subtirbia," he says.
Public Isn't Ready
The biggest problem today, Weaver
eiaims, is that the public isn't ready to
Confront the problems of the cities
bead-on.
In his first year as Secretary, Weaver
has been outspoken on such subjects as
rent subsidy programs and FHA insurance backing.

SC Petitions For Boat Ride Raided Walters Gallery
Up For City Loan
Bookstore Review.
By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
The Student Council has entered into another
phase of what it calls its fight against "profiteering"
by the Johns Hopkins Bookstore.
This phase consists of petitions which are being
circulated throughout the school accusing the bookstore of selling overpriced books and calling for a
review and subsequent change of the bookstore's policies. The reason for the petitions is to show the Administration that the students are dissatisfied with the
operations of the bookstore.
Jim Jacobs, a sophomore and a member of the
Student Council, is presently preparing a study of the
operations of the Hopkins bookstore' and other college bookstores throughout the country. The report is
due November 15th.
Sponsor Boycott
Council President Bill Reinsch has asked the proper
•
authorities in the Administration to respond to the
report by December 15th. If the Administration does
not commit itself to improvement of the situation,
Reinsch said that the Council would sponsor a boyoott of the bookstore for the second semester of this
school year.
Reinsch added that "we hope it won't be necessary,
but we are prepared to set up our own operation
bo serve the students."
Plans have already been made by the Council to
supply the students with their books should the boysat be put into effect. The important details however,
have not been worked out in the hope that the bookstore situation will be improved considerably by the
Second semester.

Henry Walters upon his death in 1931.

Hopkins Retorts
To the Editors:
For many years, a favorite
topic of journalists from coast to
coast was that "loudmouthed
slob," the Brooklyn Dodgers fan.
This fellow did everything wrong.
He even had his own peculiar
dialect, incomprehensible to anyone except another fan.
Now our earnest reporter, Mr.
Brecher, is seeking DO institutionalize a new journalistic topic,
the Baltimore fan. This "moron"
also has a funny way of talking,
but that's not his only serious
problem. Not by a long shot!
The poor guy doesn't know how
to drink champagne! Worse yet,
he doesn't even know how to buy
decent champagne! Holy Faux
Big
Pas! Golly Gaucheness!!
Deal, When did champagne finesse become a valid means of
judging a man, or a city? For
that matter, when did honest.enthusiasm, a bit unsophisticated
perhaps, but honest, become a
fault?
It has always amazed me that
jerks from every whistle-stop in
the Western World can come to
Baltimore and within a few days
set themselves up as experts on
"what's wrong with this town."
Maybe its insecurity that causes
this apparent need for tickertape welcoming parades and a
gold key to the city for every incoming student. But whatever
the cause, the uninformed criticism of Poclunk People, although
a bit rude, and slightly annoy-

ing, dont really deserve much of
an answer.
But Mr. Brecher, a noble New
Yorker, may merit some kind of
an answer. So to him this bit of
knowledge: every city has its
good side and its backside including Baltimore. If our earnest
reporter has a blind affinity for
the backsides of things, that's his
problem; it shouldnt have to be
ours weekly. If on the other
hand, Baltimore has chosen to
show only her backside to our
earnest reporter, then perhaps
she has once again evidenced the
good taste he is so convinced she
lacks.
Wallace Hopkins, '67.

We wonder as President Johnson makes the rounds
of the Asian capitals if he remembers Private Milton
Olive. Olive, a young negro was awarded a posthumous
Congressional Medal of Honor last year when he fell on
a grenade that threatened to wipe out the remaining
members of his squad.
We might speculate (without the intention of dishonoring the heroism of Olive's act) that the idea may
have occurred to him to fall on the grenade because he
had once seen Aldo Ray do the same thing in a war movie.
Further it would appear that much of our behavior is
directed by the theatrical conditioning we have received
at the hands of the film makers. Every new waitress who
appears on a job has a cinematic conception of how a
waitress is supposed to act. The motions of slopping a
cloth on a formica counter are already second nature.
It is not, therefore, terribly hard to imagine President Johnson conducting himself in office in the manner
in which he saw Ralph Bellamy interpret Franklin D.
Roosevelt or Raymond Massey as Abraham Lincoln.
While Johnson is the President he also plays the President and it is whether he does both things well that is
the heart of the Government's attitude toward the war in
Viet-Nam.
Those who saw David Lean's film revision of
Boris Pasternak's Dr. Zhivago have not found it difficult
to erase the memory of Rita Tushingham in overhalls.
Yet if we as a nation continue to confuse film with political reality it would be best to remember the obvious
irony of a British film maker attempting to capture the
spirit of Soviet Russia 1917 on location in fascist Spain
1966 for we must begin to determine whether we agree
with Professor Bernard Fall's allegation that Viet-Nam
does not represent Munich 1938 but Spain 1936.
It is useless to attempt to consider the feelings of
poor Pasternak whose novel was certainly butchered.
Nevertheless Lean's Zhivago provides a meaningful vantage from which to consider the motivation for fighting in
Vietnam and the rationality of a political war (as opposed to a moral one) as well.

Zhivago's habit of writing poetry inbetween houseealls

ONCE MORE UNTO THE BREACH
Way back in 1953 I started writing this column about
campus life. Today, a full 13 years later, I am still writing
this column,for my interest in undergraduates is as keen
and lively as ever. This is called "arrested development:'
But where else can a writer find a subject as fascinating
as the American campus? Where else are minds so nettled,
bodies so roiled, psyches so unglued?
Right now,for example,though the new school year has
just begun, you've already encountered the following disasters:
1. You hate your teachers,
2. You hate your courses.
3. You hate your room-mates.
4. You have no time to study.
5. You have no place to study.
Friends,let us, without despair, examine your problems
one by one.
1. You hate your teachers. For shame, friends! Try
looking at things their way. Take your English teacher,
for instance. Here's a man who is one of the world's
authorities on Robert Browning, yet he wears $30 tweeds
and a pre-war necktie while his brother Sam,a high school
dropout, earns 70 thou a year in aluminum siding. Is it so
hard to understand why he writes "F" on top of your
themes and "Eeeyich!" in the margin? Instead of hating
him, should you not admire his dedication to scholarship,
his disdain for the blandishments of commerce? Of course
you should. You may flunk, but Pippa passes.
2. You hate your courses. You say, for example, that
you don't see the use of studying Macbeth when you are
majoring in veterinary medicine. You're wrong, friends.
Believe me,some day when you are running a busy kennel,
you'll be mighty glad you learned "Out, damned Spot!"
3. You hate your room-mates. This is, unquestionably,
a big problem—in fact, the second biggest problem on
American campuses. (The first biggest, of course, is on
which side of your mortar board do you dangle the tassel
at Commencement?) But there is an answer to the roommate probleM: keep changing room-mates. The optimum
interval, I have found, is every four hours.
4. You have no time to study. Friends, I'm glad to report there is a simple way to find extra time in your busy
schedule. All you have to do is buy some Personna Super
Stainless Steel Blades. Then you won't be wasting precious hours hacking away with inferior blades, mangling
your face again and again in a tedious, feckless effort to
winnow your whiskers. Personna shaves you quickly and
slickly, easily and breezily, hacklessly, scrapelessly, tuglessly, nicklessly, scratchlessly, matchlessly. Furthermore,
Personna Blades last and last. Moreover, they are available both in double-edge and Injector style. And, as if this
weren't enough, Personna is now offering you a chance to
grab a fistful of $100 bills. The Personna Super Stainless
Steel Sweepstakes is off and running! You can win $10,000
and even more. Get over to your Personna dealer for details and an entry blank. Don't just stand there!
5. You have no place to study. This is a thorny one, I'll
admit, what with the library so jammed and the dorms so
noisy. But with a little ingenuity, you can still find a quiet,
deserted spot—like the ticket office of the lacrosse team.
Or a testimonial dinner for the dean. Or the nearest recruiting station.

CAMPUS NOTES
Graduate Club
The Graduate Clubroom is
open every night from 7:00 p.m.
until 2:00 a.m., except Sunday.
Food, beer, and wine are served
under the supervision of a new
bartender, Mrs, Case.
The clubroom is decorated with
12 new paintings, commissioned
by the club from Bob Wang. An
athletic display board is planned.
The present membership of

the club numbers over 500. Tom
Kelly, club president, announced
that two positions on the board
are open. Each position will be
filled within ten days of receipt
of the first nomination.

Venetian Lecture
W. R. Rearick, Assistant Professor of the Hopkins' Department of Fine Arts, will present an
18th century view of Venice as
seen by an imaginary English

gentleman and his wife on the
grand tour in 1782 at The Baltimore Museum of Art October
25 at 8:15 p.m.
The "flash-back" guided tour
of the city built on 117 islands
will be illustrated with slides of
the period, most of which are
in oolor.
Rearick has studied and lived
in Italy and devoted much of his
research and study to the arts
of Italy.
Admission is free.

a set of two one act plays at

Admission to the performances,

Ticket Office
APO is running a ticket office
on the ground floor of Shriver
Hall under the sponsorship of
the Office of Special Events.
The ticket office is open from
10:00 a.m. to 2:00 pm. Tickets
can be purchased there for
Theatre Hopkins performances
,at $1.50 per student ticket. All

to the Maria Corvin lecture October 26 and student subscriptions to the Baltimore Symphony
Orchestra.

S & G Concert
Opens Weekend
Eastern High School will be
the sight of the Big Fall concert
featuring the hit folk-rock duo
of Simon and Garfunkel 8:30
p.m. tonight.
Simon and Garfunkel write
and arrange most of their own
material. They deal with music
as a source of communication
rather than mere entertainment.
Their music has dealt with
such contemporary problems as
the lack of communication in
"Sounds of Silence" and "Gangling Conversation", self willed
alienation in "I am a Rock" and
economic inequities in "Richard
Cory."
They are gifted with the
unique ability to comprehend
and portray the soul of a young
city-dweller in an unusual and
highly engrossing manner to
their audiences.
Simon and Garfunkel have
produced a succession of hits
since their debut in October of
1964. Their hit "Wednesday
Morning at 3 A.M." has marked
them as the up-and-coming
force on the folk music scene.
